description: The food here is great. I love the menu. It's a close location and all but we still go to the one off Market as the layout in this one is weird. The bar is an uncomfortable tetris piece gone wrong. They have a host/hostess command post in front that is totally unnecessary. Take it out, add another table.
author: James S.

description: Solid, fresh seafood - mixed it up a bit with oysters, chowder (need a lot of seasoning hep though), BBQ oysters, ceviche tostada, and mussels/claims w/ fries - hard to mess up oysters so long as you clean them well and choose a good farm to get them from; the chowder was bland and need quite a bit of salt, pepper and tobasco; the BBQ oysters were pretty good, and the clams were really nice, big and meaty whereas mussles were pretty good...above avg, yes, should be 3.5 stars though
author: Richard D.

description:
I wandered across the place with two friends as we explorerd Fillmore st. I saw a man eating fish and chips through the window and had a Pavlovian moment on the spot.  We walked in and it was crowded but by some luck got seated within 5 minutes.  

We decided to all share the fish and chips, choppino, and soft shell crab BLT.  Everything was so delicious that I could not stop eating, my subconscious feeling that it would be a while before I ever return from San Diego I suppose.  The fish was crisp and juicy on the inside, the choppino was chock full of amazing seafood in a flavorful tomato broth, and the soft shell BLT was a toasty buttery dream.   Even the fries were memorably good.  Oh and the cute DIY Arnold Palmer was a nice touch.
author: Stephanie O.

description: Really tiny place had to wait 15 min for a table (not bad). The fish was awesome and tastes super fresh. Great atmosphere and the service was great. Tryed the fish and chips and the crab cakes both super awesome. Will definetly be back!!!
author: Terrance I.

description: Great service, nice vibes inside from the layout and decor and staff. Definitely try out their specials, a real treat in terms of taste and unique mixes of flavor. The cioppino is a little less "traditional", but delicious nonetheless. The tomato base is more of a "sauce" than a "soup", but the cheesy bread you get to dip into it is thrilling!
author: Tuwie N.

description:
I had friends in town visiting from NY and they were reeaally craving a lobster roll.  After some yelping and research, they decided to check out Woodhouse Fish Company.  We all ordered lobster rolls, they went with the 6 oz and I decided to stick with the 3 oz.  To be honest, I'm not sure if they just gave me a 6 oz to match the rest of my table or if the difference just isn't noticeable, but when the rolls came... I had the same amount of lobster as everyone else --- if not the same, then really close to it! I didn't feel like I didnt have enough, and I think my friends actually realized the 3 oz would have been a been a better size.  Regardless, it was really fresh and even better with some lemon squeezed on it, but I wish the lobster had a slight mayo base. If not mayo, something that would make it a little less dry.  I realize that the "expensive" lobster rolls usually don't have a  mayo base, so I guess that's just a personal taste.

Either way though, it was yum. For $17/roll though, I don't know that I loved it enough to crave it and go back.
author: Shafaq C.

description:
Holy fucking shit!  Best fish and chips ever

First of all, the cod is dipped and fried in Anchor Steam beer batter, which creates an amazing crispy, but not burnt, outside.

Second of all, the cod was a thick fillet that was so buttery and flaky you would never have guessed it was deep fried.

Then there are the fries.  They were crispy and not wet and soggy from oil.  The perfect amount of seasoning and definitely a good portion.

I also got 4 oysters, at $2.  They were delicious and very fresh.

I would definitely check out the specials next time since those were extremely tempting.  Or just go with a few people and share.

Service was quick and friendly.  It was a bit crowded so expect a wait, but the servers do a good job of coming around and checking on you.
author: Jason K.

description:
This place is SO good! I'm so glad I Yelped it while visiting SF. We started with calamari and $1 oysters (yum) and shared a lobster roll and fish & chips. 

The best thing I ever drank: Do-it-yourself lemonade. I'm ONLY serving lemonade at my house this way from now on! ORDER ONE NOW!
author: Leann C.

description:
Yesterday I went to Woodhouse Fish Company with a friend. We shared an appetizer, fried squash blossoms on slices of heirloom tomatoes, which was truly delicious. I'd never had a squash blossom before so this was a wonderful introduction. I ordered the special of the day, roasted sea bream, with mixed vegetables and a fried potato pancake. The fish was excellent. It was stuffed with garlic and basil, not the usual dressings for a fish, but very flavorful indeed. For dessert I ordered the sourdough bread pudding with rum reduction sauce and topped with homemade whipped cream. After eating a whole fish my goal of eating dessert was lofty, at best. However, what I could manage to shovel down was really good. The use of sourdough bread gave the pudding a tangy taste, offset by spices and the sweetness of the whipped cream. 

As usual the service was really great. It could not have been a better day, nor a better meal.
author: Courtney S.

description: This was the best seafood I've had in the city so far! I can't wait to go back. Try the lobster roll sandwich and the oysters. I heard they have $1 oysters on Wednesdays, will be going!
author: Aaron L.

description: Had the split top Maine lobster roll and it was delicious! They give you plenty of lobster but this place is a little bit more pricey than other places ($26 for a large lobster roll). The place was also rather small so be sure to expect a little wait. They also have oysters for $1 all Tuesday long!
author: Kristian W.

description:
I wish I loved oysters.  $1 oysters sounds great!  I came here after Yelping fried fish.  

Service was good.  Fish was flaky and tasty.  When I read the reviews I was surprised to hear "fish was greasy"... well, duh! It's fried!  But after eating there, I get what they mean.  They don't drain the fish at all before plopping it onto your fries.  So it's still DRIPPING with grease when you get it.  They were right!  Tarter sauce was good.  Love skinny fries so that made me hella happy.  

I'll be back.  Worth the drive.  Gotta figure out what's up with the iced tea thingy next time.
author: Heidi T.

description:
I've been here many times before and have had wonderful belly stuffing experience every time.. except this last time:

Came in this past tuesday night with 3 other people.  My sister and I waited patiently for a table to be ready while my 2 friends were having trouble parking.  When the 2 of us were seated, we ordered 30 oysters to start so that it wouldn't look like we were going to sit there for another 30 minutes with no food on the table.  My 2 friends came in 10 minutes later.  They weren't even in their seats yet when our skinny blonde and black haired server came and asked if they wanted drinks.  They asked for 2 more minutes to settle down so she walked away.  Then, I am not exaggerating when I say, she came back less than a few minutes later and asked in a VERY rude tone "are you guys gonna order anything else but oysters?".  That was horrible.  It made me feel like she was looking down on us as if that was all we were going to get.  So what if that was all that we wanted?   We all exchanged WTF-faces and began ordering.  She also waited impatiently while we were ordering.

By the end of the meal, we have had 54 oysters, 2 ceviche specials, a large bowl of chowder, friend calamari, lobster roll, crab roll, 1 lemonade, and 4 beers.  That's a lot of stuff!  Everything was delicious as always. Ingredients were fresh.  No complaint here (:
** The host, busser, and other servers who came by were all very nice.

After we ordered so much food, she got a bit nicer but still cold.  She couldn't even take 2 seconds to stop and say thank you when she dropped off our check later.  She just walked by and drop it off on her way to her next destination with no eye contact or thank you to us.  My friend quietly asked me at the end of the meal if it was frowned upon to only order oysters.  My 13 year old sister even said "she's really mean".  To have a kid say something like is a big no no.

I understand that it was a really busy night.  I really do and am not judging her based on that.  We're not extremely high maintenance people who demands everything to be perfect.  It's the attitude that really erks me.  I'm in the industry myself and know that that's not the way to treat your customers.  She was rude and insincere.

This was suppose to be a 5 star review but service is very important to me.  I really love this place.  But she made it clear that it wasn't a 5 star night.  If we're going to spend $180 +/- for the meal, we want to be treated that way.  If we wanted to be talked down to, we would go to Denny's after 2 am on a friday night.

I would still come back but I'll definitely ask NOT to be in her section, even if I have to wait another 30 minutes.
author: Soph T.

description:
What a delightful/refreshing experience... I couldn't be happier. The waiter was so charming, helpful and full of knowledge. 

Me and a friend decided to dine here one evening after I read all the positive feedback - boy, was it a good decision. 

We both started w/ white wine - after bugging her about (fish=white, pasta=red). I won ((this time)). 

She recalled it being very sweet like many other whites, I nodded and replied to it's lack of dryness... which I'm normally a fan of. 2 glasses later, we didn't really care anymore ;)

We decided to try oysters together - being somewhat a noobie, I asked the waiter to choose for us (again, great idea). He suggested the smaller/sweeter oysters which were so tender and flavorful I couldn't open my eyes from enjoyment. WIth just a touch of lemon and horse radish.... per---fect----to.

When it came time for the main course - we wanted to split our plates. She ordered the grilled artichoke w/ shrimp and fresh crab (basically a snack to die for). 

I HAD to try the halibut in a pouch of steamed vegi's (tomato, yellow baby potato and spinach). This really capped off the night for me. I was blown away. The flakey-ness of the fish mixed with the steaming vegi's - couldn't go wrong.

When all is said and done - I'm so happy to have experience such amazing service, food and atmosphere. 

Does Yelp give 6 stars?
author: David C.

description: Don't make my jet-lagged mistake and throw the name into google, hop on a tram and go. There are two locations and your friends won't appreciate your mistake. When we did get location two, the place was cheery, cute and service was fast. Everything tried was delicious. The other location is smaller but the decor is cuter.
author: Megan C.

description:
I'll give Woodhouse a solid 3 stars, but I really have no desire to come back.  Lunch was scheduled for 2pm, so I was starving and actually excited for some seafood-y goodness, even though seafood isn't ever my #1 pick for a meal.  

I did very little research on Woodhouse since the plans were kind of last minute, so I went in not knowing what to expect.  I arrive to find a fun and upbeat atmosphere with friendly hostesses and servers.  While awaiting on my dining companion, I decided on glass of Sauvignon Blanc (the quality was pretty crappy and it should've been a $1 less) while perusing the menu. 

This is NOT your place if you're on a diet.  Almost everything is fried on the menu--don't get me wrong, I do enjoy fried food every once in awhile, but it would've been nice to have some more non-fried options to choose from.  

We split:
-fish and chips, made with wild Alaskan cod served atop shoestring french fries (good, but super greasy--i did love the tartar sauce that came served with it)
-Baja style fish tacos, made with more cod with cabbage, pico de gallo, and avocado (really good, but hard to eat, and they were skimpy with the avocado, but I love avocado and could eat a whole one daily).

In general, the food is better than mediocre, but I thought it was a bit overpriced.  Had the entrees not been around $20+, I would've probably opted on either the Cioppino, Halibut, or Seafood pasta instead of what I ordered.
author: Jenny W.

description: This location is always packed!  I was lucky to get seated immediately upon 2 visits - once for a weekday lunch and another for a Thursday dinner.  When they say fish company - it's no joke, it's definitely all seafood.  They have a decent selection all on 1 page along with daily specials.  Prices are semi reasonable, I had the fish tacos the other night and it was ok.  I'd definitely try something else the next time - the grilled artichoke looked especially good.  Service is decent too.
author: Meredith K.

description:
Went here with a friend who had recommended this place because she claimed that the lobster roll was super delish.  I had only tried lobster rolls in NY, and so I was curious how the west coast version would fare compared to the east.  My verdict: nice attempt, but Luke's Lobster in NY is the hands down champ when it comes to lobster rolls.

They have 2 "sizes" of lobster and crab rolls.  More accurately speaking, they aren't necessarily referring to the size, but rather the amount of lobster meat that is in the roll.  The larger "size" contains twice the meat as the single size.  I believe the prices for the lobster roll (with fries) were 18 & 26.  I ordered the single size, while my friend ordered the double portion.  In my opinion, the single size didn't contain enough lobster meat.  And although they weren't super mayo-y, there was more mayo and other fillings in addition to the lobster.  And between the lobster and crab roll, the crab roll didn't even come close.  If you have to choose one, I'd opt for the lobster roll.  If I was giving a rating solely based on the lobster roll, I'd give it a 3.

Aside from the rolls, we also ordered oysters, tuna tartare, and the cioppino.  The oysters were super fresh and sweet, the tuna tartare was also amazing, and the cioppino was flavorful and satisfying on a cold night.  Our appetizers and entree definitely bumped up my overall rating from a 3 to a 4.
author: Jackie K.

description:
Updated this to 5 stars. We've been to Woodhouse a few times now and it's always been fantastic. This weekend we went back again with some guests and everyone loved their meals. Reasonably priced for the quality of food, and the service is great. I think everyone had something different and would recommend any of these: soft-shell crab BLT, NE clam chowder, cioppino, ahi burger, fish & chips, and the crab or lobster roll.

PS - The ahi burger is ground up tuna so it has the texture of a real beef burger instead of a tuna steak. Really unique and tastes awesome.
author: Tom P.

description: Went with a New England friend who's clearly been in California too long, as he was raving about the lobster roll, which I, like many, found bland and expensive. Lobster is the ONLY thing I miss about Boston/New England, so I was fully prepared to drink the Kool-aid. A really fun, lunch, however. We sat at the bar and were served yummy drinks by the happiest most charmingest waiter ever.
author: Faith A.

description: crab roll (unless you love lobster and don't mind if it's chilled). $1 oyster tuesdays. clams in white wine sauce ftw. parking sucks. go early and avoid the crowds.
author: Sherman L.

description:
I was on a walking tour of San Francisco, and the guide said this place was awesome. My husband and I actually ate here with the guide, and it's clear the staff appreciate the extra business he brings in. He gives the recommendation because the place really is a star.

I got the dungeness crab roll, and boy, was it good. Soft buttery bread encasing a heaping portion of delicious crab. All served with a side of fries and coleslaw. The star was clearly the crab. It was perfect. The fries though were also excellent, and I quite liked the slaw.

Everything I saw around me looked delicious though. So even though I practically dream of that buttery crab roll, I'd want to come back again and again to try more. The fish and chips (which my husband enjoyed) looked great, as did the lobster roll, and clam chowder. Yum...
author: E F.

description: Don't order the crab melt. Doesn't taste like crab at all. The spices overpower any crab taste. The meat could be anything.
author: Ty T.

description: Came back again for 1$ Oysters, and decided to try the Toasted-Buttered Dungeness Crab Roll -- it's a MUST. If you come here, get this sandwich. One of the best crab sandwiches I've had.
author: Kristel L.

description: My cousin and I came here on a Tuesday a while ago for lunch since Pizzeria Delfina was closed for renovations. We were initially bummed, but that all changed once we looked at WFC's menu. We lucked out cause oysters are only $1 on Tuesdays. The oysters for that day were miyagis. So yum! In addition to the oysters, we had the clam chowder (second only to Splash Cafe's (in SLO), a lobster roll, and a crab melt. The clam chowder was perfectly creamy without being too heavy, was chock full of clams, and the potato count was kept to a minimum, just the way I like it! Though both sandwiches were good, the lobster roll definitely trumps the crab melt. I just drooled on my keyboard thinking about the succulent lobster meat sandwiched in between a perfectly toasted roll. So simple, yet so amazing! The sandwiches are served with these bombass fries and some cole slaw. YUMMMMMMMMMMY. The number of M's I used cannot even begin to convey how mind-blowingly awesome Woodhouse is, so go try it for yourself, stat!
author: Audrey T.

description: We got the lobster roll and clam chowder. Both were really tasty and great for a quick lunch. The clam chowder was rich with plenty of clams. We ordered the smaller lobster roll(3 oz) and it was still plenty of lobster meat.
author: Phillip V.

description: Excellent decor and food.  The dollar oysters on Tuesday are a great value; be sure to try the bbq oysters while you're at it.
author: Matt H.

description:
$1 oysters on Tuesdays! The average wait time is about half an hour but it really depends on the time you go. If you go during peak time, be prepared to wait for about an hour. Everything about this place screams seafood. From oysters to shrimp, crab, lobster, and fish of the day. You can even order a "do it yourself lemonade" where you have all the ingredients in front of you and you get to sweeten it to your liking.

The clam chowder is absolutely delicious and I always get a cup when I go. The crab melt is one of my favorites however you can't go wrong with anything on the menu.

There are 2 locations, 1 on Fillmore and the other on Market near Castro. I tend to like the one on Fillmore because there are a few boutique shops that you can shop at during your wait time. Remember, $1 oysters on Tuesdays!
author: Christina Y.

description:
I went to Woodhouse before a movie at Kubuki with a friend. 

Pros: great friendly service
Cons: pretty average food

We were going to a late showing, and came in around 8:30 on a Friday night. We got seated in under 10 minutes - not bad. The hostess was very friendly and we ordered wine while we waited. The decor is cozy casual - waiters are wearing Woodhouse baseball caps and t-shirts instead of button downs, and there is a big screen playing scenes of the Bay along one wall. A better backdrop for dinner with friends than a romantic evening.

My friend ordered the salmon and I had the fish tacos. The food was brought out promptly and courteously by our waiter. I was hoping to like it, as the whole Woodhouse experience had been quite delightful thus far, but found that the food kind of fell flat. My tacos were tasty - fried fish, cabbage, that zesty light orange sauce found on all fish tacos - but there was really nothing special about them, and they came with no side anything. Just three pretty standard tacos on a plate. 

My friend's salmon was a large portion and served on crispy polenta, but the fish itself was a little dry and lacked the flavor you would expect from a fish house. We both enjoyed the food but had nothing to rave about.

All and all a pleasant evening for sure, but if you are looking for exceptional seafood I would try somewhere else.
author: Tory F.

description:
I've been to the Church/Market location a few times and have mostly liked it, but the Fillmore St branch was fantastic!  

I had the ahi tuna burger (a special that day)  which was really some rare tuna, diced and then smashed together with some delish seasonings.  The fries were a perfect thin/crisp ratio.   

The lobster roll that everyone Yelps about is actually not my favorite thing and seems overpriced so check out the menu for the many other good choices.

The service was friendly and polished, and the old time SF photo decor kept me looking at the walls instead of my lunch mates (maybe that is not a good thing!)  

and PS-you can go to the new James Perse store right down the block.  :)
author: John A.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place since I love seafood and everytime I walk by it is packed with people waiting outside, which is supposed to be a good sign, right?  I came here early on a weeknight and there weren't many people so there was no wait.  I ordered the oysters and fish & chips (2 pieces) - and I loved both!  2 pieces for the fish & chips is more than enough because it comes with a ton of fries and a bit of coleslaw too.   Yummy food and a plus for the friendly service!
I definitely want to come here again to try out some of the other things on the menu.
author: Selena G.

description:
Me and my boyfriend spent the weekend in San Francisco and turned to yelped to find a nice place for good seafood, good service and good conversation. With all of the good reviews for this place, we decided to check it out

Finding parking was not an issue but when we got to the restaurant we were shocked at how small it was. Maybe a max of 14 (give or take) tables with a limited bar area. We put our names on the list and was told it would be a 30 minute wait. We opted for either a table or a spot at the bar, which ever came first. We waited patiently as we saw open tables and people who arrived after us being seated. We figured they had reservations (come to find out there are no reservations here!). Every time we went up to the counter to see where our names were, we were told 10 more minutes, 15 more minutes. By this time it was almost 930 (they close at 10) and we had been waiting well over an hour. The service was horrible.
 
 Fortunately we went somewhere else. In all, would never try this place again. With the many seafood spots in Frisco, I can find one where we can actually get a seat.
author: Nicole P.

description: I went there for a late lunch and was seated right away. The service was friendly and efficient . I had a cup of clam chowder, a small size lobster roll & a glass of wine. The chowder was creamy with plenty of clams  but the real treat was the lobster roll. It was filled with lobster meat and had a little bit of mayonnaise. The roll was toasted just enough to have a crunch - it  was delicious, (the fries and coleslaw on the side were excellent too)   The tab was $39, including tip - which is an expensive lunch! I thought it was well worth it.
author: Mary S.

description:
Went here because someone said they had "amazing" calm chowder. The chowder was quite bland with a very heavy garlic accent. Doesn't really live up to true calm chowder. 

My party and I also split their Dungeness Crab Melt. It was also very bland. It was obvious that cheap crab scraps were used for the sandwich.

We both left with stomach issues. :(
author: Bradford T.

description:
Gosh..  I had heard so many wonderful things about this place and since I love seafood and sometimes crave those solid stand-by dishes -- I stopped in while in Pac Heights this afternoon.
The location is wonderful, the space is well appointed it is so clean and well light.
I was really looking forward to it.  The service was very very strong. Very attentive, polite and pro-active.

Although the food just really fell SO SO SHORT of decent.  The Clam Chowder was terribly gummy, flavorless (no acid or salt balance at all), luke warm, and beyond thick in texture.  Wow.. I was disappointed
I returned this to the server and she was very accommodating
.  I didn't say it was terrible -- I just stated that it really wasn't to my taste or the taste of a paste eating child!

Okay.. Stand up and try again. I may have just ordered the one thing on the menu that isn't very strong.
The server brought me a menu again --- so I order what she suggested a very strong dish.
Fish & Chips.  I asked if the batter was light & crispy, not too oily...
Oh well.. It came and was hot.  But again no salt balance in the crust and the crust was so oily, and undercooked - a little gummy on the inside.  The batter was definitely warm upon frying as the batter didn't crisp up - but instead absorbed the oil and got yucky..
If it was all about decor & appearance -- you would be set. Unfortunately the food just really falls TOO TOO SHORT of acceptable.
author: Paige B.

description: Not really worth the price. A nice spot, helpful, quick staff. But the crab roll is way overpriced for a mid-sized sandwich and a plate of fries...all good stuff, but didn't feel much better than a Red Lobster. The Crab Melt looked like the cheese had been melted on long before the dish was served. Sorry, but not what I'd expect for their prices.
author: Brian K.

description:
Definitely a standout in the neighborhood. My wife and I went to Woodhouse after not being able to get a table on a Friday night at one of the acronym restuarants nearby (SPQR and OTD), and I have to say, I think I enjoyed Woodhouse more than either of those two. 

We had a tuna burger that was a special that night, made in a way to emulate a mom and pop cheeseburger. They also had a sweet corn salad on the specials that night which was excellent. The standout was the halibut cooked in a parchment bag with spring vegetables, wine, ginger, and a bunch of other tasty stuff- also one of the specials. We had initially planned on ordering the lobster roll, fish tacos and crab cakes, but our server told us those would always be on the menu and that we would be wise to try the specials. We're definitely glad we did. I can't wait to go back on try the regular menu items- and probably some more specials.
author: Rakesh J.

description: Ended up here looking for a bowl of awesome clam chowder on yelp.  This is where we ended up.  Small place, friendly service, great food. Nuff said
author: Michael P.

description:
3.5 - had a craving for fish and chips and satisfied it at Woodhouse with a 3 pieces order ($14). you get 3 nice large beer-battered cod with coleslaw and fries. it was still a bit oily but hard to avoid given that it was fried in a vat of oil.

i traded one of my fish fillets for my hub's baja-style fish tacos ($14). that was good too. only complaint is the price. tough to pay $14 when you know you can get it for less elsewhere.
author: Cindy W.

description: Food has been good the five or six times I have been. They received 3 stars instead of 4 because somehow they gave themselves a $50 tip on a $120 meal. I must have been super generous that night right!  I think No...... Watch your bill or pay cash an you'll be all good. FYI crab an lobster roll are great!
author: Stephen B.

description:
went there on 9/11 Sunday lunch time

Oysters - good but not great
Lobster roll $18 - excellent but I think $26 one (more lobsters) will be even better. Fries were a little bit on the dry side.
Clam Chowder - not much of clam. too much of flour. not the best one I've had so far. 
Service - excellent 

overall - I will come back. I want to try its steam clams next time.
author: Brittney P.

description:
Staff sucks ass (and not in a good way).

Food is great!

Walk through the front door:

Host: Ummm, hellllo?
(Translation: are you in the correct neighborhood and establishment?)

Me: Hi, we would like a table for two, please.
(Hi, I am not white or Asian but I would still like to give you money for food.)

Host: OK, there are like 4 ahead of you but if you want you can write your name down on the list.
(Please don't eat here, but to avoid litigation...I guess.)

Twenty minutes later we have a table. Ten after that somebody decides to bring us water...after I asked. Our waitress sucked, maybe she was having a bad night but we are still obligated to tip so maybe you should just try and earn it. The busboy was nice, brought us water. The waiter (mohawk guy) for the table next to us was super-cool, he informed us of the specials ($1.00 oysters) and hoped we would enjoy our meal almost like he was our waiter (wish he was).

Scallops, fish and chips were good. Very good. 

But I won't be back, service was just weaksauce. In fact, we still tipped the socially-bound-by-law 15% even though it blew but I was convinced on this night to cease tipping for shitty service. Mutha-effin epiphany.

From now on if you suck, you gets no love and I thought you knew it. No note explaining why no tip either...if you really want it that bad you can ask me for it in the parking lot.
author: Carlos Z.

description:
Favorite Seafood restaurant in SF so far.

Did the lobster roll as recommended by everyone else. The Salmon was excellent...

So let's tell a little story about the chowda! They have 3 types. I was thinking OK...Boston, check, Manhattan, check and then it hit me like a ton of bricks and I now realize exactly why they call the Hartford the Hartford...check! AND BRILLIANT!! I highly recommend the Hartford. Awesome.

Like our Govenator says in some movies he's been in... I'LL BE BACK!!
author: June C.

description:
4 of us went there at 7:15pm, we were told the waiting time is about 40-50 minutes, we discussed a little and agreed to wait. 
we sit down at 8:35pm, food served at 8:55pm, by that time, all of us were just too starving to speak. when the food came, we finished everything in 20 minutes.
the timing is not that professional, not sure why they only serve party of 2, and let the party of 4 wait so long. 
considering the waiting time, flavors of food, price ($120 in total without alcohol). 
I think this place is just so so.
thanks for reading.
author: Alex W.

description: Be warned, there is always a line here....for a reason, the food is great!  If you need a seafood fix and don't want to deal with the tourist in Fisherman's Warf, this is the perfect place!  Try any of the oysters, clam chowder rocks and lobsters rolls are yummy.
author: Quinn S.

description: This place is seriously understaffed. The last 2 times we have been here for lunch there was one server for the entire restaurant. He's a nice guy but he interrupted the process of taking our order at least 6 times to go do something else right in the middle of writing down our order. We were there today at 3 o'clock in the afternoon and the restaurant was about half full. The previous time we were here - we came at 11:30 before the major lunch rush - the situation was similar. What is wrong with the management of this place? They need to schedule another server! The food is not bad - although my husband likes it better than I do; he likes to order the fish and chips.
author: Lorinda S.

description: I told my boyfriend that I was craving clam chowder. He looked up on Yelp and said we should try this place. We shared a bowl of clam chowder, he got crab melt and I got the lobster roll. Honestly the bowl of clam chowder was smaller than expected. Or maybe I was hungry and wanted to eat some more.. but it was pretty pricey for that bowl. I would rather go to the pier and get a sourdough bread bowl which feels more  like SF. The lobster roll was good. I like Sam's chowder better. Sam Chowder fills up the roll with whole pieces of lobster where you just want to pick at it. Here, they shredded it. I tried the crab melt and it was pretty good. Next time I would try the fish and sticks and maybe some calamari.
author: Phyllis N.

description:
Food: Oysters for $2 each, pretty fair price and all three different types were fresh and flavorful. Fish tacos were nice and my salad was good.

Ambiance: Whoever decorated this place should get an award. Super cool beach ocean them without being tacky. Crowded and cozy during peak eating times.

Service: Friendly, nice and very efficient. This place was fairly busy and all six employees looked like a NASCAR pit crew, working quickly and each fulfilling their assigned duties.

Price: My only slight complaint is with the price. It is probably $1-3 more expensive per item to comparable places.

Overall: Cool seafood place on Fillmore if you can find parking.
author: Binh D.

description: The clams have become hit and miss sometimse great other times not so much.  Do not try to come with a big party or you will simply be iritated they dont know how to accomidate big parties and dont really have the room we called ahead and waited over an hour and a half all the while they were telling us just another couple of minutes
author: d p.

description: I liked this place once but probably won't go back. I got the lobster roll which was good, but a little too trashed up for my taste. I think if I want lobster I want lobster done right, not served on a piece of wonderbread. My husband got fish and chips and those were nothing special. If I went again I would spend more money and get their specials. The crab and whole fish looked awesome but were really pricey.
author: Jocelyn S.

description:
Went our for lunch with the beautiful Rachel H. who writes the review below. 
Yes, she had the fish tacos which looked yummy but indeed needed more avo.
 I did not have clams though! I had oysters! They only had two varieties...and oddly enough I cant remember what they were but it was not the Kusshi or sweetwaters which are my favorite...they were a bit larger...so...yeah. I was expecting at least four different varieties..
I also had the special grilled octopus salad....OmG SOOO FREAKING GOOD....the octopus was perfectly grilled and it wasnt that tiny octopus it was a nice monster size one yummy yummy! The only thing is...the salad is a starter...and is rather small....and...I think something like $13...if it was more like $9 I would have given full stars...
author: Yuliya R.

description:
Rolled into this place prior to the Duran Duran show.  Conveniently located near the Fillmore, a big plus.  

The WAITING IS THE HARDEST PART!  So true Tom, so true.  We had to wait about 30-35 minutes to be seated.  Which I kinda expect on a Saturday evening.  Once seated the service was fairly attentive.  We decided on three dishes.  The fried Ipswich clams were battered just right.  Whole bellies with lots of meat on them.  We shared a pasta dish with scallops that was so-so.  The scallops were the tinier variety but full of flavor.  The sauce was a little overkill.  And of course the lobster roll.  It is a meaty delicious roll served just the way you like it.  The dressed version doesn't come flooded with mayo, but there's enough to make you happy.  

I washed it down with the "build your own" Arnold Palmer.  We finished off with the chocolate custard, which was quite the bomb.  Hope it's there the next time we manage to hit this place - probably before a show at the Fillmore.
author: Jeremy B.

description: Excellent seafood restaurant, great staff and menu. Delicious whole pan fried granzino
author: Owen S.

description: $1 oysters on Tuesdays- they aren't the best oysters, but for a buck? Sure, why not. I don't know why I came here when I'm on a weight-loss diet, but I had a hard time finding something on the menu that wasn't fried or slathered in sauce, but it is a seafood restaurant, so I guess I get it. I went with the steamed clams/mussels and it was really delicious. Get's pretty busy during lunch time.
author: ALISHA W.

description:
I heart woodhouse. I want to marry their oysters. Super fresh seafood prepared and seasoned perfectly. 

I've never been to the other location, since this one is closer to where I live, but since this is the second location, I'm sure the other one will not disappoint.

Bring on the seafood coma!!!
author: jcie k.

description:
The crab melt ($12) is one of the best I've ever had. The bread is perfectly grilled, the crab is actually served hot and the cheese is melted evenly. I've had crab melts at other places and they're always lacking in one area or another...so props to Woodhouse! They know how to get it done. The sandwich comes with a side of french fries (so good). 

Also had the crab cakes...delicious. You can get 2 for for $12 or 3 for $15. It's kind of small so if you're sharing or really hungry, definitely get 3. It comes with this aioli sauce drizzled on top. So good!!

To polish off dinner, we ordered an apple pie a la mode ($7 + more for ice cream).

Love the location, staff is super friendly, overall a great little lunch or dinner spot.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
YUM!

Crab is always great. The stuffed artichoke also. The clam chowder is not the best, but  probably much better than you're used to (and they have "hartford" style, which is both the manhattan and new england combined). Prices are quite reasonable for seafood. Service is good. Overall, a very solid choice.
author: Yana N.

description:
First time I had a tuna special .. big pieces of tuna steak sort of medium rare or  rare, with spinach, really good.  I was trying to be low-carb that day, so that was perfect and the portions were pretty big compared to anywhere else I'd get tuna steaks, and a little less expensive too.
  My friend had the lobster roll sandwich, she was impressed with the big pieces of lobster in it.  I have to say it looked delicious.  (It's $18, looks like you can get a larger one for for $26 I think.)  
   Another time I had the Fried Oyster Po' Boy.  Not bad, but I realized this sandwich is for people who really like oysters, not for someone like me that only likes Po' Boys because I could care less what you deep fry and stick in a sandwich as long as the dressing and herbs/spices are good.  These are big deep fried oysters, not cut-up little pieces that are deep fried.  Next time I'm trying something different, maybe crab cakes or the Louie Roll (crab sandwich), the fish tacos ..  fish and chips. .what else? I don't know, but everything I've seen looks pretty good.  Fries are crispy, cole slaw is good.  Oh!  The Sourdough Bread Pudding is delicious.

The white wines. .  not so much!  The Riesling is not sweet at all, which is weird, because Rieslings are supposed to be very sweet.   Actually the other 3 white wines my friends and I tried were not sweet for what they were supposed to be. . a Muscadet that was not sweet at all, and 2 Sauvignon Blancs, one that I liked ok, but the other was just tolerable.  Weird.  Whoever chooses their wines must really not approve of sweet wines, or thinks they don't go with the food.  . but then why even list any supposedly sweet types of wine at all?

Oh the waitstaff is pretty nice, I like them and I've seen them be pretty patient both with little kids when I went early (after school time?) and with a little old man once who was talking the waiter's ear off.  Cute.  :)
author: Muriel D.

description: Just had an excellent dinner with my gf here on Fri night: Wedge salad, oysters, crab cakes, artichoke, and a bottle of the sav blanc. We were luckily seated at the end of the bar, so we had our own little space. The only reason for 4 and not 5 stars is bc I think it would have been way too cramped being seated anywhere else. Still, highly recommended!
author: Z A.

description:
I'm a total fan. This place has great ambiance. Our server was helpful. and the food was tasty - had the fish tacos. mmm mmm good.

Check it out!!
author: Vanessa J.

description: Went for the $1 Tuesday special. It was awesome, but the wait was loooooong and they don't take reservations. Expect to wait for a while when you plan ahead and you'll be fine. It's worth it!
author: Vithiet L.

description:
This is a relative rating to the one in the Castro more than a straight up rating.

5 big negative factors here:

1. $1 Oysters were not that good at all and 4/6 had shell in them like everyone is saying. Learn to shuck an oyster.

2. Prices here are roughly 30-50% higher than the Castro location. That means beers, clam chowder and all other food items except for the oysters on $1 Tuesdays.

3. No Tuesday beer special like the Castro location.

4. The clam chowder does not taste as good as the other location either. It was bland and unexciting

5. douche crowd
author: Victor B.

description:
Today we binged on seafood. Fresh seafood. Lots of it. You see, it was our 1 year wedding anniversary and in our book, celebrating with (lots of) fresh seafood is how we roll.

We must have gotten to WFC at just the right time because a table opened up that was perfect for 2 grown ups and a little dude in a stroller. No attitude about the kidlet, just a nice friendly welcome and a speedy seating at a clean table.

We tend to over do it at times like these and today was no exception. Though, we did exercise a little restraint and opted out on oysters. What we did go for was the large lobster roll, the 3 piece fish and chips, and the seafood iceberg salad. The roll and the fish came with perfectly fried thin and crispy fries, and a little cup of coleslaw. 

The lobster roll was jam-packed with lobster, and in a word: delicious. (which is a lot coming from me since I'm more of a crab fan) The grilled bread is New England all the way.

The fish on the fish and chips was light and crispy and fried to absolute perfection. Not at all greasy or soggy.

The salad was covered with crab. So much so, that you could barely see the lettuce underneath it all. 

Did I mention how yummy and crispy and lightly salted to perfection the fries were? I did? Well, they were that good.

A couple of general things worth mentioning about WFC: they use crushed ice in their drinks (fun! totally old school). The wine list, while not adventurous, is nicely priced and well-paired with the menu. The service is friendly and prompt. The prices are fair. Not too cheap, not too pricey. Parking, not so great, but that's the City for you... what're you gonna do?

Woodhouse Fish Company is one of those places that doesn't always pop to the front of my mind when I'm thinking of places to eat in SF, but when it does, I always wonder why I don't think of it more often. Especially since it's so consistently yummy and just a nice place to spend an afternoon. Or 45 minutes. We have a kidlet now and the days of lingering over lunch with a bottle of wine are a luxury we can't afford. Lots and lots of fresh seafood on the other hand...
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
My wife wanted a protein/vegetable so we decided to vist here on GHD based on the number of Yelp recommendations. To avoid a long wait we arrived at 4:30pm and were given a nice table immediately. By the time we left (6pm) there was a line waiting for tables.
For an appetizer we split the Dungenes Crab Cocktail and the main dishes we shared were the Cioppino and the Stuffed Artichokes based on a recommendation from Jake, our server. We topped off the meal by splitting a Chocolat Mousse. All of these dishes were substantial and outstanding and well worth the total $75 bill. 
We especially enjoyed the television in a picture frame which showed views of local fishermen and docks. Only disappointment was I wish I had the Arnold Palmer instead of the Anchor Steam.
This visit would actually rate 4.5 stars and we will definitely now we know where to park on a Saturday afternoon. This is our top seafood restaurant for the bay area.
author: carson s.

description:
What a LOVELY place.

I love this place....from the decor to the food to the staff.

Clam chowder is excellent and so is their garlic bread. OH the garlic bread... i'm in love....

Lobster roll: simple, SMALL (the bread is fairly small) and refreshingly delicious. The french fries that comes with it are seriously quality fries. YUM! 

Baja Fish tacos: yummy to my tummy, don't forget to use some tabasco to complete the dish!!

always seems to be crowded during peak hours, so come a little earlier to avoid the lines. Will come back again to check out their oysters :-D
author: Emily T.

description:
Props to Woodhouse, not for the amazing tricks they can do with their raw material, but precisely because they know when to hold back and serve seafood simply and deliciously. The best, and I suppose most important, thing to say is that they know how to cook fish. As in, they understand that fish is not supposed to taste like a McDonald's Fish Fillet (surprising how many restaurants "aim" for this particular accomplishment). They know that lobster isn't supposed to be rubbery and that fish shouldn't ever be "well done." 

The only thing I took away an extra star for is the overabundance of breading, oil and fried stuff on their menu. Except for their $1 Oyster specials (YAY), they don't seem to do much raw or grilled food. Hey I get it - mayo and breadcrumbs are seafood's natural homies. But come on people. We don't have to put it on everything.

That said, this is where I'm going when I want fish but don't want Asian food.
author: Michi V.

description:
Woodhouse deserves special recognition for helping my family with a difficult situation, a situation staff had no idea we were facing, one we never mentioned. They solved an invisible problem, which helped my stepmother and me enjoy a calm dinner with my father. The father I am gradually losing.

You see, my father has Alzheimer's. Since he is in fabulous physical shape, he doesn't "look" impaired or frail. However, eating out with him in restaurants has become challenging. About three years ago, I suggested Le Colonial, not knowing my father had this problem, as I live out of town, and it was before his diagnosis. It was too noisy for him, and disorienting. He started to become agitated. Eventually, he WAS agitated, and yelling. A new or noisy environment sets it off.

My father still does well at Pasta Pomodoro because he's a regular who's eaten there hundreds of times. But my stepmother gets weary of endless Pasta Pomodoro. And since I no longer live in the City, my stepmother wisely wants me to have a treat. So while she and I were out for a movie, she suggests we call my father and ask to meet us at Woodhouse on Fillmore. He has already been to Woodhouse on Market, and loved the lobster roll, so this seemed like a prudent compromise.

So we arrive around 6:30 p.m., Thursday, Dec. 29. Since I don't know these people's names, I'm going into specificity. We get on the table list. A handsome, bearded, 29-ish and incredibly sweet man takes our name and says about 15 minutes for a table. Perfect. By the time my dad arrives, we will already be seated, and that will reduce potential for agitation.  (If the answer had been 45, we would have left.) Woodhouse is a calmer, quieter, family type place. We should be OK, with luck.

But 15 minutes went by and no table. (Meanwhile, we have a whole separate set of worries: While my dad has never been lost, it could happen any day.) The host is super nice, apologizes for the delay, and reassures us he is working on our table as soon as another party leaves. He explains so nicely - the reason for the delay is the others ordered dessert. Completely understandable. Meanwhile, my father shows up. Whew! But now the table worry rises into view again. After 3 minutes, my father is starting to pace. We can feel his agitation coming on. Meanwhile, my stepmother and I are starting to pop in every few minutes to check status, trying to act cool. And the host patiently says to me "Don't worry, you can wait outside. I promise I will come and get you." He's just so sincere, I absolutely trust him. Meanwhile, Dad is pacing. Not frantically, not something that anyone who doesn't already know him would likely notice. But we know what it means. At one point, immediately after we had explained the table status to my dad yet again, he goes in himself and talks to Peaceful Lovely Bearded Man (I feel he needs a name). I have no idea what he said to PLBM, but my dad came back outside again. Meanwhile as we are waiting outside, PLBM came out on his own at least two times to give us updates on the table status and to reassure us. Then, after perhaps 30-40 minutes total, PLBM comes out to tell us our table is ready! Whew! Now waiting 40 minutes for a table on Fillmore on a busy holiday weekend is nothing radical. Heck, that might even be an average night's wait. But in our situation, it could have been a dangerously long fuse.

So we sit at our table. My dad is a former Coast Guard officer, as well as a lighthouse buff, so the décor is the perfect soothing ambiance for him. And the next wonderful staff member steps up to the table: our server. (Management: We sat in first booth on right across from counter.) She was a beautiful woman, about 25, slightly round face, with long dark-brown hair pulled neatly into a ponytail. The female equivalent of PLBM aka PLUnbeardedW. She was so unhurried, so patient. She listened to our menu questions. She connected with us, easily and naturally. I realize everything is going to be fine. The invisible situation has been defused. 

My dad got his Lobster Roll again and loved it, although he never remembered eating before at Market Street. I had crab cakes - yum. However, I was modest and only ordered two, so I was still kinda hungry. PLUW recommended the Hartford chowder, which is a combination of New England (white) and Manhattan (red) chowder. Another YUM. I need to hurry back for that.

La pièce de résistance of this lovely dining experience? Dessert. Dear, sweet PLBM came over to our table as we were finishing our dinner, and apologized again that we had to wait. Not only did he apologize, he offered to buy us dessert! Now that's service. We went for the sourdough bread pudding, which was yummy too.

PLBM, I hope you recognize this tale, and our party, so you know how truly grateful I am. Exactly what great service should feel like: Invisibily meeting the needs of your customers even when they never directly express them to you. Thank you.
author: Kate G.

description: I'm hooked.  My current favorites are the various clam chowders.  The fish tacos are delicious and generously portioned.  The fish and chips and the fried calemari are solid but not as extraordinary as the chowders and tacos.  Looking forward to trying the rest of the menu.
author: Sue B.

description: I found this place when I was out with my wife just walking by and decided to check it out this past weekend. I was in the mood for no BS seafood and a beer. The place was crowded but we got seated in 10 minutes. Comfy and non-pretentious, this fish shack serves very good seafood dishes. I started with the crispy calamari. It was crispy fried, tender, and nicely seasoned. I chose the lobster roll and was not disappointed. The meat was not overdressed and very tasty. The decor reminded me of being by the waterfront and the noise level was not too bad. Going back here soon!
author: Marvin C.

description:
Do i love seafood? A resounding yes.
And if you are like me, and enjoy seafood, do yourself a favor and come here.  A simple and tasteful lil joint with fresh and delicious seafood.  That's all you need to know right there, it's really that simple.  But i'm gonna be more long winded, so bear with me.
I think this place is the perfect place to have lunch on a sunny afternoon.  We made the short jaunt over to fillmore and ordered the oysters, calamari, shrimp sandwich and crab cakes.  All are definitely above average and i think i fell in love with that sandwich at first sight.  The bread was fantastic and they were very generous with the amount of shrimp that was offered.  

This was my first experience at Woodhouse, and you can bet that it will not be my last.  Affordable prices, fresh seafood and a quaint atmosphere to dine in.  As you can see... i'm beaming here, do yourself a favor and go and do the same.
author: Felix W.

description:
Let me start of by saying that the service is absolutely wonderful. Everyone was extremely helpful and friendly and the wife and I really appreciate this level of service in the rare occasions when we experience it. The restaurant has a "Key West" feel to it and is chic yet relaxed.

We started off with a garlic and cheese bread that was to die for. I think this was actually the highlight of the meal. It comes straight from the oven and you want more and more!

My wife had the crab sandwich. It was well made but we have had better. I had the Monkish special. The fish was well cooked but lacked flavor and depth. 

Overall the restaurant was good for the price and the service was exceptional.
author: Daniel P.

description: This place has such amazing lobster rolls. The calamari was mouth watering amazing. Absolutely love the food. The tv fooled me thought it was a moving picture in a picture frame. But the service was decent the place was clean and again food was worth the money spent...
author: Daisy B.

description: Good lobster rolls but not as good as what I've tried on the east coast and definitely overpriced.  If you've never had a lobster roll before, I'd recommend it, but personally I've had better.  There was a lack of flavor.  The french fries are pretty good though.
author: Kash S.

description:
This place was recommended to us by an SF resident, so we decided to give it a try.

Small place, with limited seating, but they are up front about the wait.  They were pretty accurate too.  There were six of us, and we were seated within 10 minutes (very reasonable!)   

Most of us had the dungeness crab which was delicious.  You are expected to crack the crab yourself, but it was fresh!  We tried the grilled crab and the steamed crab; both were good, but when we go back, I'm leaning towards the grilled crab.

Other menu items we tried were the clams, the chowder, the ciopppino...ALL were good!  

Great food, great price, and the service was wonderful.  Everyone was so nice.  We'll be back!
author: Mae A.

description:
Came for: neighborhood-casual yet Fillmore-fitting weeknight din
Will come back for: neighborhood casual yet Fillmore-fitting grubs

I recently returned for another visit here for their casual and clean ambiance that serves good seafood (including good fried kind too!).  It's on the pricey-end, but it's probably a premium to be a part of the Fillmore gang.

Crispy Calamari ($12): they keep it simple, with well-balanced crispiness and flavor; it's the appetizer that keeps giving; somehow as a party of 2, we never seem to finish it!

Fried Ipswich Clam Roll ($15): I had my first ipswich clam roll here; it's fried clam pieces placed into a sweet bread-type roll, served with little bit of cole slaw, fries and tarter sauce on the side (bonus points for on the side!); the fried clam concept didn't make my tastebuds dance, but I did enjoy it nonetheless.  Note, ipswich clam fans can get it as an appetizer if desired.

Ahi Tuna Burger ($15): my friend had this and we were too busy talking for me to ask how it was; it looked good, but anything special.

Split-Top Maine Lobster Roll ($18 for the small): enjoyed one of my first lobster rolls here; like it for the quantity of lobster, little amount of mayo, combined with the sweet-bread roll; didn't appreciate the price point.

Cioppino ($22): unexpected winning dish!  it has a kick to it and I enjoyed it thoroughly; not crazy about the price point on this one either.

The little touch that pushed this up to 4 stars is their Do-It-Yourself Arnold Palmer!  They bring out a stand with tea, lemon juice, and simple syrup, which you then mix yourself to suit your taste bud.  What a GREAT concept, especially when I was going to ask for "not too sweet".

Take-Away: Repeat worthy place in the neighborhood, it especially stands out as a casual, yet stylish place.  It is Fillmore, afterall...
author: Carol K.

description:
I am not into seafood but decided to try this place since my wife is a big seafood fan. The restaurant is very small and can get crowded, but there is a good feel to it. We had to wait for a table but I was surprised that I actually liked the food and the atmosphere. My wife loved it!! We tried the fish and chips and a sandwich (can't remember the name) and both were great.

The servers were polite and very attentive. They were nice to change an order for us as well. We will def go back.

Parking on Fillmore st is a challenge, so walk or use public transportation!
author: O N.

description:
The decor of this place reminds me of Pearl Oyster Bar in NYC, so I was instantly enamored. Then I saw seafood cioppino on the menu and as the reigning cioppino queen, I had to order it.

The cioppino had a good amount of seafood and was a good portion for $20. I wish they had a "lazy man's" version with the crab meat removed from the shell.. That was a bit too hands-on for my taste. The tomato broth was thick and very spicy! I asked for two sides of bread to mop up the remaining broth and it was quite a filling meal.

I'd also recommend the do-it-yourself lemonade, which is similar to what you find at Rose's Cafe. Delish!

I would come here again, but only the Fillmore location. The Market location is kind of old and stuffy.
author: Wendy T.

description:
I was sooo excited to try their main lobster roll and when I bit into my first piece of lobster meat, it was SUPER SUPER dry and had no flavor at all. It reminded me of that canned crab meat that you can buy at Trader Joe's (yes, and this was supposed to be fresh lobster). The bread was buttery and warm, but I just could not get over the fact that the coleslaw tasted better than the lobster.

Maybe it was because I was there around 9:30pm, but I would expect a place that closes at 10pm daily would prepare for lobster orders this late at night. I was sorely disappointed. 

+2 stars because the clam chowder was decent and the service was good....I'm just so sad about my lobster roll, guys. I'll be back another day (during the day) to give this place one more try...
author: Stefi C.

description: This restaurant fits in perfectly with the Fillmore neighborhood vibe. It's casual with huge airy windows that give the small space an open feel. The food and beverage was lacking, however and the whole menu is just a few ticks above fast food. The wine list was very sparse and the beer choices were equally puny. In general I found the food to be lacking in flavor.  The beer battered fish for fish and chips was the exact same thing used in the fish tacos. The batter was doughy and turned to mush at the first sprinkle of malt vinegar. The oysters were good but not fabulous. They were lacking in liquor and brine. Clam chowder was ok. The peach cobbler desert was bland and was served at a scalding temperature having been blasted In the microwave too long. No ice cream accompaniment only some whipped cream which quickly dissipated.  With all the SF choices for seafood, this place needs to step up their game.
author: C S.

description:
Four stars for Woodhouse Fish Company, one star for me.

Woodhouse:

I had been eying the cioppino, but decided to go with the more inventive stuffed artichoke. Delivered on top of a salad, it's a generously sized and packed with crab and shrimp. I thorough enjoyed making a mess while devouring each and every leaf, and more than once I forgot proper etiquette and licked my fingers. Sorry neighboring diners, it was just too good. Loved there was no mayo in the seafood, but healthy yelpers be warned, the artichoke was definitely grilled up with plenty of butter and oil.

We ended with another excellent dish, the strawberry shortcake. Large enough for the three of us to share and get quite a few scoops each, we all thought it was rather tasty. Not to mention the joy that comes with realizing you are having strawberries in January. Another "we are so lucky to live here" moment.

Me:

Our waitress, after I asked if I could get my salad dry, suggested cocktail sauce instead, something she does as a healthy alternative. Ah, hello girl of my dreams. One star for me not doing anything about it.
author: Jason B.

description:
OMG..yes!!!

$1 oysters are not as creamy and slightly more briny than HOg Island $1 oysters.  LOVE IT!!

Both the Lobster and Crab sandwiches are amazing.  The price point is a little steep but I think its worth it.  Both sandwiches are stuffed with their respective meat and soaked in butter.  Not much extra fluff here,  I like how they showcase the meat instead of trying to do some crazy shit that fucks up the flavour. Does it get better than that?  NOPE!

The service is great...generally...I would say the dudes are nice than the gals. 

Their specials are also TOP NOTCH!!  Love coming here. If you can get in the door before 7pm you should be good. anytime after that be prepared to wait.
author: Spanky M.

description:
Great wine. Excellent lobster rolls. Great oysters! They had one type of oyster that was small called Kumamoto which is great for people who don't normally like that oyster taste but want to develop their palate. Aka: an intro to oysters oyster. Very sweet. Buttery. 
The other two types of oysters were great too. 
No trouble getting a seat at 12:30 on a Sunday afternoon either which was shocking. I'm sure it's worse during happy hour. 

Note: Lobster rolls mysteriously have two prices, as do the crab rolls. The smaller price is for 3 ounces of lobster, and the bigger is for double the lobster. It all comes on the same yummily buttered and toasted bread roll though. So you can either have a reasonable amount of lobster or your lobster can be dripping down your arms. Your call. Three ounces may not sound like a lot but it's a good portion size. Seven dollars more lets you be a fattie. Fries are great. Well-seasoned and perfectly crisped. Cole slaw was whatever.
author: Candice L.

description: we love this place for food and atmosphere. there is a waitress here that tends to be very abrupt(we've had her twice) dont know her name but shes very tall. she acts like we should feel privileged to be eating there. she would not let us sit at a table even though we ordered a bottle of wine because we were waiting on 2 more of our party of 4 to show. we had to sit by the door with our bottle of wine on our knees. the place hadnt even filled up and did not fill up the entire time we were there(a good 3 hours)it was a slow evening. they could have showed a bit more class. the rest of the staff and hostess were wonderful though and made sure to give us a more relaxed calm evening.
author: Dante D.

description:
Been coming here almost every week since Crab Season began.  I seriously love the Dungeness Crab and if it was a crime to eat too much crab I might be locked up.  I just L-O-V-E it here- I always get it hot, steamed in white wine/butter/lemon.  It takes some time and effort to eat it but I can't get enough.

The artichoke is also amazing as are the oysters and french fries.  I hate to admit it, but today we also had the onion rings (with all of the above) and they were PERFECTION.  

I love that you can show up on a weekend afternoon and get seated, and the service is always pleasant.  It is also great for kids.  Love love.
author: Anne E.

description:
We were passing by here yesterday after doing some casual shopping and decided to just hop right in and get a couple of appetizers to please our snacking.

We were greeted once we got into the door and we sat down at the bar. Our waitress seemed nice at first and took our order. We had decided to stick to water as it was 100 and something degrees outside. We saw the sign outside which intrigued us on $1 oysters. We ordered three of them at first to try out. They are served raw. Presentation is pretty nice, its served on a ice platter with a lemon wedge, parsley for garnish, and house sauce? maybe ketchup I dont know.

We also ordered a bowl of clam chowder. After the waitress took our order she seemed so pissed off at us and started to give us attitude. It was probably because we only ordered water, soup, and three oysters...but after we had the three oysters we went ahead and ordered 8 or something more. WE JUST CAME IN FOR AN APPETIZER we told her. Its not like we wanted a full on meal. No need for the rudeness.

The food was good, but I wouldn't come here for the service. I loved the atmosphere and the seating arrangement. It was a bit warm in there tho even tho it was warm outside. I want to be comfortable when I'm eating.

Overall, I wouldn't come back for the waitress. She could've checked her attitude at the door.
author: Nathalie N.

description: Oysters were fresh and calamari was tasty. Fish tacos were awesome. Fish was crispy and avocado on it was perfectly ripe and fresh. A little messy to eat but not a complaint as it was because the fish pieces were so big and the tortillas were brittle. Beer on tap was phenomenal and paired well with the food. Only reason I didn't give 5 stars was because the service was slightly lacking. Went in around 2:30 and the hostess was the only front of house employee. She seemed a little......umm.....hungover? But as we ordered more food and beer she seemed to lighten up a bit. But still, great place and great food.
author: Josh O.

description:
I will definitely be coming back here.  

Party of 6 stopped in on a Friday night and only had to wait 40 minutes.  Unfortunately, since the space is so small, waiting meant grabbing drinks at the bro-bar up the street.  Meh.

Anyway, once we sat down, our server was awesome (too bad I can't remember his name) - he was funny, attentive, and honest when we asked his opinion (which for some reason is a rare quality in servers - pet peeve of mine).  2 hours and 2 bottles of bubbles later, our whole party was very full and very happy.  

I recommend the crab louie salad - they don't skimp on the crab at all.  The oysters and calamari were also delicious (although slightly pricey).  Dessert did hit a dull note - but that was the only part of dinner I left unsatisfied with.  Overall, I can only fault Woodhouse for the small waiting/bar area and the sweets - otherwise, I loved it!
author: Nicole K.

description:
Oh my.  Oh my.  Lobster rolls... seriously.  The most amazing reward for my post-yoga-I-deserve-a-treat days.    Juicy, fresh, sweet lobster meat  on a crispy (read: butter drenched) roll, worth every bite.  That's how I count calories these days... worth it?  Not worth it?  

The wine list is reasonable and pretty ordinary.... New Zealand Sauv Blanc is a must for this place, and they have the J Pinot Gris I have on my list, so I can't knock that.  The desserts were good, but too big, no one needs 12 ounces of bread pudding, really.  They should have key lime pie here, that would be the ultimate post-lobster roll dessert.  They should NOT have strawberry shortcake in December, it's just plain wrong.

Service is lovely, people are kind.  But then they usually are if you give them a chance.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Woodhouse Fish Company, 415-437-CRAB, served up a delicious meal. The wait was substantial on a Thursday night (minus one star) but I think this is just another indicator of its goodness and popularity.

I had the halibut cooked in parchment paper (wow... it was literally served in the bag of paper!! vegetables, fish, and spices floating in butter), while my friend had the tuna burger. We enjoyed two desserts as well... strawberry shortcake (my favorite!!) and chocolate mousse.
author: Flora B.

description: Unfortunately, I've got to disagree with most of the reviews. I'm not a particularly picky person but I've have much better food elsewhere. Our group ordered the smelt side dish, the highly touted lobster roll, dungeness crab roll, and fish and chips. To our dismay, the fish batter was very oily and greasy. The chips were dripping oil onto the napkin underneath. The smelt was ok but just lightly battered. The lobster was rather tasteless and seemed to have be just thawed from the freezer. My side dish of sauteed garlic vegetables was overcooked and mushy. On a good note, our Asian waitress was very friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable.
author: Frank F.

description:
this woodhouse fish is a fillet of the main branch. haven't been to the main so this is a standalone review.. this woodfish has pice of ships on the wall. and a video showing fisherman in the process of  fishing.
and landing fish.

sampling:
-clam chowder, cup (4,95): creamy, smooth witth pieces of  clams and potatoes, nice oyster crackers.
-fish &  chips (3) 12.50: lots of nicely fried salty shoestirng potatoes,
3 rectacular pieces of alaskan cod that was surprising bland.  beer battered with anchor steam? who cares? haven't had one fish & chip where the beer made the difference.  IT"S THE FISH,  S__

hook, line, and sinker:
-fast, friendly service (good people)
-maybe the halibut (18-20?)_or lobster roll(15?) would have been better.
-nice ambience
-metered parking.
-cod obviously previously forzen..-
author: Victor G.

description: wonderful. softshell crab blt... fuking forget about it! good knowledgeable staff. all around great experience
author: James R.

description:
Definitely a fan of this place. I was in SF for a conference, and would make my way down to the Castro every evening. Woodhouse was the halfway point between my hotel and the Castro, and I would stop in every evening for a bite to eat. I ordered the same food every evening, something light, a cup of New England Clam Chowder, and a wedge of iceberg with bleu cheese dressing. Both were perfect, but it was the staff that made this place wonderful. Knew my order by the second day, and would often come out and talk with me as the place was not terribly busy at the times I was eating. 

Definitely recommend this place. It will always be synonymous with San Francisco for me. Love this place.
author: Lyle R.

description: My husband and I recently walked down to Woodhouse from our house and we are so  glad we did. We had a great experience. We did not have reservations but were promptly seated at the bar. I liked the hooks under the bar for coats - very convenient since San Franciscans are often dressed in layers! Now onto the food...it was delicious! We got the lobster roll and cioppino. The roll just melts in your mouth and the cioppino is really flavorful. We will definitely be back!
author: Jess L.

description: Always fresh and tasty, no matter what you order. Don't miss the lobster rolls, they are delicious. If you want to come in the evening you probably should make a reservation as it gets pretty crowded and the wait is long. You can also come outside of lunch and dinner times.
author: Christoph I.

description: Delicious fish n chips, I also love their wedge salad and the pasta specials they do!!
author: SF M.

description: Nothing beats $1 oysters on Tuesday nights! The crab salad is also delicious and comes with a generous portion of fresh crab!
author: Melanie S.

description:
So glad to have a delicious seafood place in the hood!  I've been here a few times, and the service has been exceptional.  The wait staff provides really good, reasonable recommendations and are totally down to accommodate any weird requests you have.  Once, I was there and couldn't decide on the clams or muscles; the server came to my table with a medley of the two which was delicious.  I was smitten by him and the medley,

The pictures really just don't do the place justice; everything I've tried there I highly recommend; chowder, oysters, artichoke, clams, muscles, garlic bread, french fries, absolutely heaven.  I've noticed a lot of people rave about the lobster roll; although it is good, I don't think it's the absolute best thing on the menu.  The roll itself is a little too buttery for me, but nonetheless it's still really good.

The decor is pretty cool and although it is a small space, they do turn tables quickly and as a patron, I don't feel rushed.  This place and Bar Crudo are probably my favorite seafood places in SF!
author: Laura H.

description:
I loved every aspect of my lunch here at Wood House. From the nautical decorations, to the nice waiter, to the DELICIOUS lobster roll...I was in heaven.

The wedge salad was to die for (beets instead of bacon! Imagine that!), and I loved the do-it-yourself-lemonade. 

Also had a bite of the crab melt (ehh), and the fish tacos (good...but every fish taco is good in my book.) Just get the lobster roll and forget about the rest!
author: K. D.

description:
Before I'd even finished my meal here, I already wanted to come back...because there's so much more I want to eat! I came here w/ the bf last week because we wanted to try a new restaurant and indulge ourselves a little. We had steamed Littleneck clams, Swordfish, half a crab, English peas, and strawberry shortcake. The seafood was fresh and delicious; prepared simply yet uniquely. The sandwiches, which I did not have room for, sounded so awesome too! Crab melt, lobster roll, CBLT!! CBLT = BLT with a whole softshell crab wedged in, their special for that day. 

The parking was ok, not impossible. The wait- we got lucky and only waited 10 mins or so on a Saturday night. Definitely coming back.
author: Jessie C.

description:
Parking:  difficult, but doable even on a Friday night (3/4/11 around 7pm).

Location:  great, walking distance from J-Town, Kabuki theater, nightlife, etc.  Inside of the restaurant is clean and well decorated! Not much of a wait on a Friday night either!

Calamari:  pricey, but worth it! the batter was tasty and there was a lot of juicy squid rings and legs!

Large Dungeness Crab Roll:  AMAZING!!! Well worth the $25! packed with lots of tasty crab meat and the buttered toasted bread complemented the crab!

Service:  quick, attentive, and pleasant!

Definitely coming back (or visiting the one on Market) for the garlic bread and fish and chips!
author: Ali and Nick G.

description: Overhyped and overpriced. The food was good but not phenomenal. Probably 3-3.5 for the lobster roll, slaw and oysters. The wedge salad was just okay. The blue cheese is on the tangy side- which I don't prefer. The chowder is very potato-y (is that a word?). Not great chowder but not bad. Service was more like a 2 star. Very Unattentive and they were not busy so that was not an excuse. The more I think about the service (or lack of) I think it's closer to a 1. There were several things from twice not noticing we had no silverware or napkins and serving our apps and drinks then taking the silverware and not giving us new ones when entrees were brought out. Never asking if we wanted refills or other drinks while we had empty glasses, not asking how our food was or if we needed anything (the standard check back once food is served), and having to flag her down to get the bill and then again to take our card. I liked the lobster roll but admit it was nothing special. It was a standard and fresh roll. Fries were not fresh (frozen) and overlooked. Slaw was tasty. But because of bad service I won't be back.
author: Piper W.

description:
came here for an early lunch and the was told i could sit wherever i wanted.  i hear it gets crazy packed after 1pm, so definitely try to check it out on the earlier side if you don't want a wait.

i've been craving a lobster roll for awhile and finally got a chance to try one at woodfish.  the lobster rolls comes in two sizes (3 oz lobster or 6 oz).  being that i've been craving this for ages, i decided to go big and get the 6 oz.  the lobster roll was delicious, packed full with fresh lobster meat.  the lobster wasn't covered in mayo dressing either, so you can really enjoy the sweetness of the lobster naturally.  the sandwich came with coleslaw and crispy skinny fries, which were also great.  even though i devoured the 6 oz and was completely stuffed afterward, i probably would have been full going for the 3 oz portion and would have saved myself $8.  

overall, it was a great dish.  i'm from new england and grew up on lobster and crab rolls, so it's hard for me to digest spending over $20 (this lobster roll was $26)  on these rolls on the west coast.  with that said, the lobster roll was definitely high quality meat and really fresh.   service staff was friendly and i'll definitely go again to try their fish and chips or crab melt.
author: Helen T.

description:
The wait staff at Woodhouse is really nice and efficient. 

The food was adequate.

However, it is in a bit of a ritzy shopping district so it is overpriced and I have had a better crab sandwhich in my life. Hence the 2 star rating... which Yelp says should mean "Meh. I've experienced better."

I am a foodie. I don't mind paying lots of money for good food. I would not go back to Woodhouse for the crab sandwhich but there are a few things on the menu I might go back and try.
author: Alex W.

description: I have been here many times and the one thing I can say is that this is one of the most awesome seafood eateries around.  The last visit was yesterday at 2:30 PM and it was still packed.  I can honestly say I have not a bad meal here- ever.  The attention to seasoning, freshness, and consistency is amazing.  I also love the video of the sea dock on the wall.  It makes me feel like I was eating on a fishing dock and provides nice ambiance.  I want one for my home.
author: Darin E.

description: Really good!  The standouts here are the crab roll, lobster roll, and oysters.  I've been to both locations and both are great.  I'm a fan.
author: Leila ..

description: This place is absolutely divine. The crowd here is mixed, and if you want to dine alone, you can do so without feeling awkward. From their clam chowder, baja tacos, to the do it yourself arnold palmer, this place knows how to make your belly happy. The service is also very good, and staff is friendly. I haven't tried the oysters there yet, but plan to the next time I go back!
author: Mars F.

description: I haven't tried anything else here, but the Dungeness crab roll from Woodhouse is one of the most delicious things I have had in SF so far. The crab is piled on high and the Texas toast is super buttery. The Fillmore location is a bit cramped but is still nice, and the service is pretty good.
author: Shannon S.

description:
Have always been very impressed with the food that comes out of SF. My husband and I headed to "Woodhouse" for a late lunch and found parking atrocious (but it is the city) so not too bad. 
     -Arrived around 4:30 on a Sunday
     -Upon walking in we found the place quaint and on its way to being very occupied. Decor was nice and made us want to stick around for yum yum food. 
     -Ordered the cup of clam chowder as recommended by most Yelpers! I would have to say it was very good although I am not a clam chowder connoisseur. Lots of clams and potatoes and zero pieces of sand. Overall great flavor. Are these things that make for good chowder? If so, thumbs up.
